citeinfo.origin: U.S. Forest Service, Region 9, Hoosier National Forest (Data Compiler)
citeinfo.title: HOOSIER_NATL_FOREST_MGMT_IN: Hoosier National Forest Management Areas (Hoosier National Forest, U. S. Forest Service, Polygon Shapefile)

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Forest Service, Region 9, Hoosier National Forest

citeinfo.othercit: This data set was provided to personnel of Bernardin, Lochmueller & Associates (BLA) by personnel of the Hoosier National Forest.

descript.abstract:
The following is excerpted from Hoosier National Forest metadata -
"This data set shows the management areas as defined in the Hoosier National Forest Land and Resource Management Plan for alternative 5."
descript.purpose: To provide the locations of the Hoosier National Forest management areas.
descript.supplinf:
Hoosier National Forest management plans and areas are fully discussed in the Land and Resource Management Plan (January 2006). This document is available from the Hoosier National Forest at 812-275-5987 or downloadable in .pdf format from
http://www.fs.fed.us/r9/hoosier/planningdocs/final_docs/2006_documents.htm

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.0 (Build 2195) Service Pack 4; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.1.0.780

citeinfo.origin: U.S. Department of Agriculture, U.S. Forest Service, Hoosier National Forest
citeinfo.title: Hnf_ma
citeinfo.othercit: Contact Hoosier National Forest for source details

srcinfo.srccontr: Previous repository for the data presented here

procstep.procdesc: Unknown process to create the ArcInfo coverage. See Process Contact.

Bernardin, Lochmueller & Associates received an ESRI ArcGIS 9.2 coverage named "hnf_ma" from the Hoosier National Forest in May 2007. ArcGIS 9.2 was used to export the coverage into a shapefile format. The fields "hnf_ma_" and "hnf_ma_id" were deleted. The field acres was recalculated using software generation.

This metadata was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit, v 2.6.1) and MP (Metadata Parser, v 2.7.1) software written by Peter N. Schweitzer (U.S. Geological Survey). The errors generated by MP were all addressed and corrected.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated

attr.attrdef: Other names for the management area

edom.edomvd: This management area protects and enhances water-based recreation opportunities, visual quality, and riparian values. This management area is associated with canoeable and fishable streams, rivers, lakes, and reservoirs.

This area is a general forest with large areas of old forests and scattered openings associated with a variety of forest plant communities. A variety of tree species is present, but shade-tolerant species may dominate some communities over time. There is a higher percentage of edge habitat in this management area than in most of the forest. Habitat in these areas is best suited to wildlife that uses large hardwood trees and a mosaic of different-aged hardwood forests.

This management area emphasizes diversity for wildlife species requiring a mix of early and late successional vegetative types and age classes. It is associated with a mosaic of forest conditions dominated by hardwood trees and their associated understory habitat. Horizontal and vertical diversity are present in the forest. Management is more intensive than in other management areas. This area will provide habitat for previously declining populations of wildlife, particularly Neotropical migrants.
Congressionally designated Charles C Deam Wilderness Natural succession is the dominant process.

This management area creates a physical setting that provides an opportunity for solitude and a felling of closeness to nature. The area is general forest with the appearance of extensive stands of forest dominating the landscape. Over time, extensive stands of natural-appearing forests of shade-tolerant species will characterize the area.

This management area creates a physical setting that provides an opportunity for solitude and a feeling of closeness to nature. The area is general forest land with the appearance of extensive stands of forest dominating the landscape with some openings. Over time, stands will be dominated by large mature and over-mature trees that will provide habitat for late-successional species.

These areas provide for recreational facilities and developed sites. They include campgrounds, picnic areas, boat ramps, swimming beaches, and other areas intended to serve large numbers of people. User fees are collected at most areas.

Research Natural Areas (RNAs) - This designation allows unique ecosystems to follow natural processes for scientific purposes. Research may be conducted in these areas to improve understanding of natural processes and to increase the benefits from our forests.

Special Areas -- Special areas include unique or unusual botanical, ecological, geological, scenic, historic, prehistoric, or zoological values and other areas which merit special recognition and management. Management of the areas will emphasize the protection, perpetuation, or restoration of their special features and values.
Experimental Forests -- This management area provides for research and scientific study of forest ecosystems.
Managed by Indiana Department of Natural Resources

overview.eaover:
Hoosier National Forest management plans and areas are fully discussed in the Land and Resource Management Plan (January 2006). This document is available from the Hoosier National Forest at 812-275-5987 or downloadable in .pdf format from
http://www.fs.fed.us/r9/hoosier/planningdocs/final_docs/2006_documents.htm

distinfo.distliab:
No claims to accuracy are made on these data. It is intended to be used only for general planning purposes. Detailed planning or analysis will require more accurate data.

metainfo.metuc: This metadata file is intended to accompany the data set identified and received from the BLA. It should not to be altered or summarized. BLA does not support secondary distribution. If this data set was received from anyone besides the BLA, this metadata file and the data set it describes may lack integrity.
